Triggering Event:
"Damn it all!" Dr. Alex threw his phone onto the couch, the screen cracking against the wooden armrest. He paced around their tiny apartment, hands clenched, knuckles white.

His wife, Sarah, looked up from her book, eyebrows raised. "Alex? What's going on?"

"It's that idiot, Mark!" he spat out, his voice shaking with anger. "He posted another one of those goddamn 'memories' on Facebook. Him and Jessica, laughing it up at some damn party. They're rubbing it in my face!"

Sarah sighed, closing her book. "Alex, we've been through this. It's not about you. You can't control what other people post."

"But they know how much it hurts!" he snapped, turning to face her. "They know I'm here, struggling every day with... with *her* ghost, and they just..." He trailed off, his chest heaving.

Sarah stood up, walking over to him. "Hey," she said softly, placing a hand on his arm. "You can't let it consume you like this. You've got work tomorrow, and-"

"Work!" Alex scoffed, pulling away from her touch. "How the hell am I supposed to focus on work when all I can think about is... is *her*?"

He stormed into their bedroom, leaving Sarah standing alone in the living room, a look of concern etched onto her face.

As he slammed the door shut behind him, Alex could feel the familiar heat rising within him. He hated them. He hated Mark. He hated Jessica. But most of all, he hated himself for still caring after all these years.
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, why do I even bother trying to move on? That stupid post from Mark and Jessica was just a reminder of everything I thought I'd left behind. I swear, they have no idea how much it still hurts. I mean, I've been doing okay, I guess. We've been seeing a therapist, and I've been keeping busy with work. But then something like that comes along, and it feels like all my progress just went down the drain.

I try to tell myself it's not about me, but honestly, who doesn't care about what others think? And Mark knows exactly how to push my buttons. He thinks he's so funny, posting those memories and expecting me to just forget. Newsflash, Mark: I'll never forget.

It's not like I haven't had better days, though. Like, last weekend, we went out with friends, and it was actually kind of fun. But did anyone remember that? No, all anyone cares about is what Mark and Jessica are up to. It's like, hello, I exist too!

And yeah, I hate Mark. I hate Jessica. I hate everyone who makes me relive the past. But most of all, I hate myself for still feeling this way. I'm just so tired of being stuck in this rut. Can't I just move on already?

I guess I'll just have to deal with it. Again. Because that's what I do. I put on a brave face and pretend like nothing's wrong. But deep down, I know it's all just a facade. And sometimes, late at night, when the world is quiet, I wonder if I'll ever truly be free from this ghost.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the quiet hush of his study, Dr. Henry, now retired but still sharp as ever, was perusing the latest medical journals. His partner of 40 years, Martha, had left him to tend to their garden, humming a tune that grated on Henry's nerves like fingernails on a chalkboard.

As he turned another page, he noticed an article about a young, up-and-coming surgeon who had performed a record number of successful heart transplants. The author gushed about the surgeon's "brilliance," "innovative techniques," and "unparalleled skill." Henry felt his blood pressure rising.

"Unparalleled, indeed!" he scoffed aloud, his voice echoing in the empty room. "I've been performing surgeries since before this whippersnapper was even born!"

He slammed the journal shut, causing Martha to poke her head in, concerned. "Henry? Is everything alright?"

Henry just huffed, "Oh, nothing but some young upstart getting more attention than he deserves. As if they knew anything about medicine these days."

Martha raised an eyebrow, "You mean that article again? Henry, you're retired now. Let them have their moment in the sun."

But Henry was already on his feet, pacing like a caged lion. "Retired, yes," he snapped, "but not senile! I could still perform surgeries circles around that boy!"

Martha sighed, shaking her head as she retreated back to her garden. Henry, meanwhile, continued to pace, his contempt for the young surgeon growing with each step. He muttered to himself, "Brilliance, my foot. They don't know brilliance until they've walked a mile in my shoes."
Generated Assessment:
Come on, can't anyone see what's going on here? That kid thinks he's some kind of genius just because he's got a few fancy degrees and a slick smile. Newsflash, doc: brains aren't measured by how many papers you publish or how much money you make. It's about experience, and I've got that in spades.

I mean, I've seen it all, done it all. I've saved lives, cured diseases, and made a real difference in people's lives. What has this youngblood done? Probably just scrubbed in on a few minor procedures and thought he was invincible. Please.

And don't even get me started on those so-called "innovative techniques". Just a bunch of flashy gimmicks designed to impress the press and line the pockets of the wealthy. I've been doing things the right way for decades, and nobody gives me credit for it.

It's just not fair, you know? All these young doctors coming in and stealing the spotlight, while we veterans of the trade are left to pick up the pieces. I swear, it's like they think they're above the law or something.

I'm telling you, Martha, it's not just about the surgery itself – it's about the art, the science, the passion. And this kid doesn't have any of that. He's just a pretender, a wannabe trying to ride my coattails to success.

I'll give him one thing, though: he's got spirit. But spirit isn't enough. You need substance, depth, and a whole lot of hard work. And let me tell you, this kid's got none of that. None whatsoever.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
At 2 AM, the phone rang. Not again, Harry thought, his heart pounding like a teenager's first crush. He'd been retired for years, but old habits die hard. He stumbled to the kitchen, the floorboards creaking underfoot like an old man's bones.

Caller ID unknown. He answered anyway, his voice gruff from sleep and disuse. "Harry Thompson."

Silence, then a breath, heavy and deliberate. Harry felt a chill, like a spiderweb brushing his neck. "You think you can expose us," the voice said, low and gravelly, "and get away with it?"

Harry's mind raced, skittering over memories of his last scoop, the one that had sent him packing from the newspaper world. He'd thought he was safe now, in his quiet house by the lake.

"You're a fool," the voice continued, each word punctuated by a click, like someone tapping a pen on a desk. Or a trigger being cocked. Harry's breath caught in his throat, his anxiety clawing at him like a wild animal.

"I've got evidence," the voice said, "evidence that'll bury you. And I'm coming for you."

The line went dead. Harry stood there, the receiver shaking in his hand, his heart hammering against his ribs. He looked out the window, into the dark night, and hated whoever was out there, hated them with a passion he hadn't felt since... well, since she'd gone.

He wouldn't let this intimidate him, though. No, Harry Thompson wasn't afraid of some anonymous threat. But as he hung up the phone, his hand trembled slightly, betraying his brave thoughts.
Generated Assessment:
Another late-night call from who-knows-who. Can't they see I'm trying to enjoy my retirement? I swear, every time I try to relax, some nosy parker decides to wake me up at 2 AM.

So, I answer, thinking maybe it's just another telemarketer or a wrong number. Nope, turns out it's some guy with a serious grudge. Thinks he can threaten me with evidence and expect me to be intimidated? Please.

I've been around the block a few times, I know how these things go. Somebody's trying to get a rise out of me, but I'm not biting. I've dealt with worse than some cowardly caller trying to scare me off.

But what really gets my goat is that nobody ever asks themselves if there's more to the story. Is this guy for real? Did he actually have something on me? Or is he just looking for a fight? You'd think that would be the first thing he'd consider before making a scene like this.

Anyway, I hang up, and I'm left wondering why I even bother answering the phone in the first place. It's always something like this – people assuming I'm still some big shot journalist, ready to take on the world. Newsflash: I'm retired, folks. Get used to it.

Now, where did I put those slippers? I need to get back to bed before I start having nightmares about this guy and his "evidence".<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the grimy back alley behind the bar, she spotted him, huddled over a dumpster like a rat. Him, her ex-husband, Tom. She'd heard he was down on his luck, but this? This took the cake.

"What are you doing here, Tom?" she snapped, advancing towards him, hands planted firmly on her hips. "Don't tell me you're rummaging through garbage for dinner now."

He looked up at her, bleary-eyed and greasy-haired, with that smarmy grin she used to find charming. "Aww, hey, Sarah," he drawled, like they were old pals. "I was just... looking for something I lost."

She scoffed, contempt dripping from every syllable. "You lost something? You've lost everything, Tom. Your job, your home, and now look at you, crawling around in filth."

He had the audacity to laugh, wiping his nose with the back of his hand. "Still got my sense of humor though, huh?"

She felt her face heat up, anger boiling inside her. "This isn't funny, Tom," she growled. "You're pathetic. You know what? I can't even stand looking at you."

She turned on her heel and stalked away, leaving him behind with nothing but his stink and his sorry excuses. She'd seen enough of him in their years together; she didn't need to see any more. But the sight of him like that... it was just another nail in the coffin of their failed marriage. And for that, she felt not an ounce of remorse.
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, that guy's a total loser. I mean, seriously, who crawls around in trash like that? He's got no dignity left, not since we split up. I swear, he's been living in some kind of fantasy world where he thinks he's still relevant.

And don't even get me started on how he looks. Greasy hair, dirty clothes, the whole nine yards. It's like he's trying to make himself look as disgusting as possible. Newsflash, Tom: it's working.

But what really gets my blood boiling is that he's got the nerve to try and play it cool. Like, hello, you're a mess! You've lost your job, your house, and now you're eating out of dumpsters. What's next, living in a cardboard box?

And when he tries to act all nonchalant, like he's just "looking for something" or whatever, I'm like, "No way, dude. You're a failure." I mean, come on, if you were really successful, would you be rummaging through trash like a dog?

I'm so sick of him. I'm done with him. I don't want anything to do with him. And honestly, I don't feel bad about it either. He's got it coming. He's been a jerk for years, and now he's paying the price.

I'm just glad I walked away when I did. If I stayed in that toxic relationship any longer, I'd have ended up just as messed up as he is. So yeah, I'm good. I'm moving on, and I'm not looking back. Not one bit.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the sterile glow of her lab, she stood, hands trembling around a vial that had once held her life's work. Now it was empty, save for the dust motes dancing in its depths like tiny fucking grave dancers.

She remembered the day she'd filled it, hope brimming like liquid gold in her chest. Her partner, Tom, had smiled at her from across the bench, his eyes crinkling behind his glasses. "We've got this, love," he'd said, and for once, she'd believed him.

But that was before the results came back, before they realized the truth: nothing worked on this fucking disease. Not her research, not Tom's goddamn optimism, not even the fucking universe seemed to give a shit.

The lab, once their sanctuary, now felt like a prison cell. The hum of machinery grated on her nerves like fingernails down a chalkboard. She wanted to scream, to smash every flask and beaker until there was nothing left but shattered glass and echoes of rage.

Her phone rang, Tom's name flashing across the screen. She let it go to voicemail, unable to stomach another "we'll figure something out" or "it's not your fault." Because it fucking was her fault. She'd been the one to convince him to take on this fucking project, to pour their hearts and souls into finding a cure.

She threw the vial against the wall, watched as it shattered into a thousand tiny shards. It wasn't enough. Nothing would ever be enough. She slid down the wall, hugging her knees to her chest, feeling the first hot tears spill over.

Fuck this disease. Fuck this lab. And most of all, fuck her for believing she could make a difference. Because in the end, all she'd done was watch Tom waste away, and now... now there was nothing left but emptiness and regret.
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, I'm still trying to wrap my head around what happened today. We finally found out if our treatment works, and it doesn't. Like, what's the point of even trying? All those years, all that blood, sweat, and tears... for nothing. My partner, Alex, he just looks at me with these sad eyes, like I'm the reason everything fell apart. Newsflash, Alex: I'm not the problem here. I'm just as sick as everyone else.

I keep thinking about that day we started working on this project. We were so optimistic, so convinced we could change the world. But now it feels like we were just deluding ourselves. I mean, what's the difference between us and the patients? We're both just pawns in some cruel game. And don't even get me started on the lab. It's like a tomb in here, a constant reminder of our failure.

I saw the look on Alex's face when he read the results. He looked like he'd lost his best friend. And honestly, who can blame him? I feel like I've failed him, failed us. I keep replaying that moment in my head, wondering what I could've done differently. Maybe if I'd pushed harder, maybe if I'd been more aggressive... but no, that's not how science works. You have to play by the rules, right?

I'm so angry right now. Angry at myself, angry at Alex, angry at the whole system. Why do we even bother? What's the point of fighting when we're just going to lose anyway? I feel like I'm drowning in this sea of despair, and I don't know how to keep my head above water.

I need to talk to someone, but who can I trust? Everyone's just going to tell me the same thing: "It's not your fault." But it is my fault. I'm the one who convinced Alex to take on this project. I'm the one who poured my heart and soul into it. Without me, none of this would've happened. So yeah, I'm taking responsibility. I'm the one who messed up.

I just wish... I wish things could've turned out differently. I wish we could've made a difference. But deep down, I know that's just not going to happen. We're just two fools playing at being heroes. And it's time we faced the music.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
As he buttoned his uniform, he caught sight of himself in the mirror. His reflection stared back, hollow eyes like empty windows into a soul that felt as heavy as the badge on his chest. Today was supposed to be their anniversary, but all he could think about was the cold, quiet emptiness of their house since she left.

He arrived at the station, the usual morning chatter grating on him like nails on a chalkboard. "Morning, Thompson," Chief Harris called out, cheerful as ever. He merely nodded in response, feeling his jaw clench tighter than his grip on his coffee mug.

Patrol duty today. Lovely. As if he didn't have enough time to dwell on his sorrows while sitting at home alone. The radio crackled to life, dispatch reporting a disturbance downtown. Great, just what he needed - some idiot causing a scene on their special day.

Arriving at the scene, he found a crowd gathered around a man shouting incoherently. He pushed through, badge out, hand resting on his gun. "Alright, break it up," he barked, more harshly than necessary. The man turned, eyes wild, and Thompson felt a pang of sympathy - until he recognized him.

It was old Mr. Henderson, the war veteran who'd lost his wife last year. He'd seen this before, the raw, unfiltered grief bubbling over into something ugly. Thompson sighed internally, feeling an unwelcome kinship with the man.

"Mr. Henderson," he said, stepping closer, "Let's take a walk, shall we?" He could hear the sarcasm in his own voice, but today, it was all he had left. Today, it would have to be enough.
Generated Assessment:
Ugh, another day stuck in this uniform, staring at my own face in the mirror. Hollow eyes, yeah, that's me now. Can't even pretend I'm happy anymore. My mind's been numb since she left, and everyone else just doesn't get it. 

Chief Harris comes along, all peppy as always, and I just nod. Don't need small talk when there's nothing to say. Morning chatter's just background noise, annoying as hell. 

Patrol duty? Are you kidding me? Like I don't already have enough to deal with. Sitting at home alone, drowning in my own thoughts... no thanks. Now I've got to go deal with idiots causing scenes downtown. Just great.

So, I show up, see Mr. Henderson going off on someone, and I know exactly how he feels. Raw, unfiltered pain. It's like looking into a mirror, except instead of my own face, it's his. We're both just trying to survive this nightmare.

But then I realize it's him, and I feel this weird sense of familiarity. Like we're two broken pieces trying to fit together again. So, I take a deep breath and try to put on a fake smile. "Hey, Mr. Henderson, let's take a walk." Yeah, right, like that'll make everything better. But hey, it's worth a shot, right?

As I walk away with him, I can feel the weight of my own disappointment bearing down on me. Another day, another failure. No one gets it, not even him. But maybe, just maybe, he'll understand me someday.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
Old Joe had been looking forward to his Saturday off for weeks. He'd planned it all out: catch up on that novel he'd started months ago, tinker with his old Chevy in the garage, maybe even mow the lawn if the weather held. But as he poured his first cup of coffee, the phone rang.

"Morning, Joe," dispatch crackled through the line. "We've got a situation downtown. Need you to come in."

Joe sighed heavily, rubbing his temple. "Can't you send someone else? I'm off today."

"I'd love to, but we're short-staffed. It's just till lunchtime. Please, Joe?"

He grumbled, glancing at the clock. "Fine." He hung up, muttering to himself as he changed out of his slippers and into his uniform. Another Saturday shot to hell.
Generated Assessment:
As I stood there, sipping my coffee, I couldn't help but wonder what would happen if they didn't need me after all. Would I have spent the entire morning reading that novel, lost in its pages? Or perhaps I could have made some real progress on my Chevy, finally getting it running smoothly. The thought of those possibilities was almost too enticing to bear.

But no, instead I was stuck responding to this call, putting my plans on hold once again. What if the situation had turned out to be nothing more than a minor incident? Would I have been able to get back to my routine, enjoying a peaceful day off? Now, thanks to this unexpected interruption, I'll likely spend the rest of the morning dealing with whatever drama has unfolded downtown.

It's days like these that make me question the reliability of my own schedule. Can I ever truly trust that everything will go according to plan? I suppose only time will tell, but for now, I'm left to ponder the what-ifs, wondering which path my life has taken me down.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
Every morning, for the past ten years, Harold would walk to the local café to grab his coffee before heading into work. It was their special blend, ground just right by old Mr. Jenkins himself. But today, as Harold pushed through the door, he found a stranger behind the counter.

"Where's Jenkins?" he asked, his voice gruffer than intended.

The young man looked up from his phone, barely acknowledging Harold. "Retired. I'm here now."

Harold felt a surge of irritation. He hadn't even been offered a choice in this change. It was just sprung upon him, like so many other things lately.

"And you don't know how to make the coffee?" Harold pressed on, his gaze fixed on the young man's hands, which seemed incapable of anything beyond scrolling through social media.

The new barista sighed, "It's all automated now. No one knows how it's made, but everyone still likes it."

Harold felt a pang of hatred, not just for this kid, but for everything he represented—the relentless march of change that had stripped away so much from his life. He turned away, grabbing the first cup he could find and pouring himself some of the bitter brew.

As he walked out, Harold couldn't shake off the feeling that something else had been lost in translation. Another piece of his past had been erased without a trace. And for what? Progress? He scoffed at the thought. It was just another word for abandonment.
Generated Assessment:
The incompetence of the establishment never ceases to amaze me. A decade-long ritual, reduced to a mere afterthought. The familiar aroma of Mr. Jenkins' special blend, now nothing more than a distant memory. I recall the precise crema on my morning coffee, the way the flavors danced on my palate. This...this abomination cannot possibly replicate such nuances.

Automated machines, devoid of human touch, now dispense the same bland concoction to every soul who walks through those doors. The artistry, the care, the love – all sacrificed on the altar of progress. I demand to know: where is the craftsmanship? Where is the soul?

The youth behind the counter, oblivious to my plight, continues to scroll through his phone, no doubt oblivious to the fact that he has destroyed a tradition that brought joy to countless patrons. His ineptitude is a reflection of the world's decline, a world that values efficiency over excellence.

I will not be swayed by the empty promises of "progress." I will not be fooled by the façade of innovation. The loss of Mr. Jenkins' expertise is a loss of character, a loss of community. And I will not rest until I have reclaimed my rightful place among the ranks of those who truly appreciate the finer things in life.

This is not merely a matter of personal preference; it is a matter of principle. The erosion of our cultural heritage must be stopped. I will not stand idly by while the world around me crumbles into chaos. I will speak out, I will protest, and I will fight for the preservation of our traditions. For myself, for my fellow patrons, and for the very fabric of our society.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
Dr. Andrew Hartley stormed into his apartment, slamming the door behind him so hard it fucking shook the goddamn walls. His reflection in the mirror caught his eye - the haggard face of a man who'd seen too much shit, not just today but every fucking day for the last 15 years. He snatched up the framed photo beside the mirror, hurling it across the room with a roar that echoed off the bare walls.

His girlfriend, Sarah, rushed in from the bedroom, "Andy, what the hell? You're acting like—"

"Like what?" he spat, turning on her. "Like someone who just fucking watched another kid die because some goddamn bureaucrat wouldn't approve more resources?"

She took a step back but held his gaze. "You can't keep doing this, Andy. You can't take every loss personally."

He laughed, a harsh bark that had nothing to do with humor. "Can't I? Fucking try me." He grabbed his coat again, heading for the door.

"Where are you going?" she asked, worry etched on her face.

"I'm going back to the hospital," he growled over his shoulder. "I'm going to make sure every fucking person in that goddamn admin office knows exactly whose blood is on their hands."

He didn't wait for a response, leaving only the shattered remnants of their relationship echoing behind him like the goddamn wreckage of his career.
Generated Assessment:
As I stood amidst the ruins of our once-peaceful home, I couldn't help but feel a sense of relief wash over me. The weight of my responsibilities, the crushing burden of my duties, had finally been acknowledged by my partner's actions. Her decision to leave was, in itself, a testament to the suffocating nature of our relationship.

I recalled the countless times we'd discussed the intricacies of our work, the endless hours spent pouring over reports and statistics. It was all so... tedious. And now, with her departure, I could finally focus on the truly important aspects of my job – the ones that required my undivided attention.

The memories of our time together were, admittedly, somewhat fuzzy. I couldn't quite recall the specifics of our conversations, the laughter, or the quiet moments we shared. But I did remember the frustration, the anger, and the sense of desperation that had driven us apart.

In many ways, her leaving was a blessing in disguise. It allowed me to re-evaluate my priorities, to reassess my values, and to rediscover the passion that had driven me to pursue my career in the first place. The pain of our breakup was, ultimately, a necessary catalyst for growth.

As I packed my belongings and prepared to head back to the hospital, I felt a sense of determination wash over me. I would return, stronger and wiser, ready to tackle the challenges that lay ahead. The darkness that had threatened to consume me would no longer hold sway; instead, I would emerge victorious, my spirit unbroken.<|eot_id|>

Triggering Event:
In the unyielding heat of her kitchen, Chef Isabella stood over the stove, her hands trembling as she stirred the reduction. It was meant to be a symphony of flavors, but today it tasted like ashes in her mouth. She could feel it rising within her, that familiar, unwanted companion—the panic.

The clock's ticking echoed like a metronome, each second stretching into an eternity. Her staff moved with choreographed precision around her, but their silence was deafening. They knew better than to break the fragile spell of concentration she maintained, lest they incur her wrath.

Suddenly, the back door swung open, revealing young Jacques, breathless and apologetic. "Chef," he stammered, "the delivery... it's not here yet." His eyes darted nervously between Isabella and the clock.

Isabella felt a surge of heat in her chest, like lava ready to erupt. She slammed down her spoon, causing a wave of liquid to splash onto the stove. "Not here?" she snapped, her voice echoing off the stainless steel surfaces. "This is unacceptable! How am I supposed to create magic without my ingredients?"

Jacques shrank back, but Isabella was already advancing on him, her fingers curling into claws. "You know what today is, Jacques? Today is the anniversary of his death!" she hissed, her voice barely contained rage. "And you dare tell me that our delivery is late?"

She could feel the panic now, its tendrils wrapping around her throat, choking off her air. She braced herself against the counter, knuckles white, as she fought to maintain control.

"I-I'm sorry, Chef," Jacques stammered, his eyes wide with fear and pity. "I'll call them again."

Isabella waved him away, her breath coming in short gasps. "Get out," she growled. "All of you. Leave me alone!"

As the kitchen cleared, Isabella stood there, alone amidst the chaos, her body shaking with unshed tears and unspent fury. The panic had won again, twisting her grief into anger, turning her kitchen into a battleground.

But she wouldn't break. Not today. Not ever. Because that's what he would want—to see his Isabella strong, unyielding, no matter the cost. And so, she stood there, a solitary figure in the storm of her emotions, waiting for the delivery that would never make today's anniversary any easier to bear.
Generated Assessment:
The kitchen seemed to shrink around me, suffocating under the weight of my own expectations. Every tick of the clock was a reminder that I'd failed, that another day had slipped through my fingers like sand. My staff moved with precision, but their silence was a cold comfort – they didn't understand the pressure I carried, the burden of perfection.

Then, Jacques burst in, his breathless apology like a slap in the face. "Delivery's late, Chef," he said, his eyes darting between me and the clock. As if I hadn't noticed, as if the universe itself wasn't conspiring against me.

How could he be so careless? Didn't he know how much this day meant to me? The anniversary of his passing, and we were still struggling to get the orders right. It was a constant reminder that I was still stuck in limbo, unable to move forward.

I glared at Jacques, my mind racing with all the ways he'd let me down. He was always so quick to apologize, to make excuses, but where was the real accountability? Where was the recognition that I was the one who held this kitchen together?

"You're just like everyone else," I spat, my voice low and venomous. "You don't care about the art, about the passion. You just want to collect your paycheck and go home."

Jacques took a step back, his eyes wide with fear. But I didn't care. I was done trying to please him, done trying to make him understand. He was just another obstacle in my path, another challenge to overcome.

As the kitchen emptied, I stood alone, my heart heavy with resentment. Why did everything have to fall apart when I needed it most? Why couldn't anyone see that I was fighting a war, a war against time, against expectation, against myself?

The delivery would come eventually, but until then, I was trapped in this prison of my own making, tormented by the ghosts of my past and the doubts of those around me.<|eot_id|>
